attack_pattern.name: Application DoS

obstacle.name: Application impossible to use
obstacle.definition: A webinos application is no longer usable

obstacle.name: Badly configured policy
obstacle.definition: The webinos policy settings are poorly chosen and the application is denied access to too many APIs

obstacle.name: Bad default policy
obstacle.definition: The default webinos policy settings are too restrictive

obstacle.name: Bad user-selected policy
obstacle.definition: The user has selected bad policy settings

obstacle.name: The Application is auto-updated by an attacker
obstacle.definition: The application downloads an update automatically and installs it. However, the update was issued by an attacker rather than the application author

obstacle.name: Application signing key not checked
obstacle.definition: Update procedure does not check that the update signing key matches the original signing key

obstacle.name: Application developer signing key compromised
obstacle.definition: The application developer's signing key is leaked to the attacker, perhaps due to it being embedded in a source file or another means.

probability.rationale: There has been a history of key compromise by developers who are careless or who are attacked.

obstacle.name: Hosted application is attacked through content injection
obstacle.definition: The application's hosted components are attacked via a content injection attack, possibly XSS.

obstacle.name: JavaScript injection triggers security violation
obstacle.definition: Injected javascript causes the application to trigger security warnings and get disconnected by the PZP or webinos runtime

obstacle.name: JavaScript injection overwrites webinos.js
obstacle.definition: Injected javascript prevents the application from accessing PZP functionality by overwriting webinos.js

obstacle.name: Application blacklisted after negative reviews
obstacle.definition: The application is given several negative reviews and warnings on app stores and social networks, putting it on a blacklist

obstacle.name: Webinos backdoor
obstacle.definition: The webinos platform is updated to specifically target this application and render it unusable

probability.rationale: Commits to the project are reviewed by a limited number of people. A backdoor would be relatively hard to insert and would be accountable

attack_pattern.intent: Harold has developed a webinos application he is very proud of. Unfortunately it is not receiving much attention because another app (which he believes to be inferior) is extremely popular. Harold decides to get rid of the competition, which he feels will be best for everyone: he gets the recognition he deserves and users get a better experience.

motivation.description: Users become unable to reliably use a certain app

structure.attack_obstacle: The Application is auto-updated by an attacker

attack_pattern.consequences: Depending on the application, users might simply no longer be able to use the app. They might also lose access to some data. The developer could lose money, reputation and social contacts. The developer might lose their job.

implementation.description: Harold performs a denial of service attack on an application, rendering it unusable by end users.
